text: i’ve always wondered this. in content staging, what’s the difference between ‘staged draft’ and ‘staged proof’? is there a reason to keep it in ‘staged draft’. i typically publish it to the staging domain right away.
Is there a way to make a quote available to the general public? Love the easy stripe integration and want to make a product available to even anonymous customers!

It’s effectively a way for teams to communicate whether a page is ready for publishing or still needs work.

If you save as draft, meaning it isn’t ready to publish. It will appear in staged draft. If you publish to staging, it will save it in staged proof.

Additionally similar to the normal CMS if something is in draft it can’t be viewed by going directly to it’s URL.
This is handy for solutions partners that may be building out parts of a site or doing a redesign, and want to send a link to the end-customer to review. That way they’ll only see pages that your team designated as ready to go.
Gotcha. That makes sense. Thanks, Jon!

Parts are built in the CMS. The actual course content itself is actually inside the HubSpot App itself.

So yes it’s built in HubSpot, built by HubSpot, but it’s not all “on” HubSpot in the sense of everything being in the CMS.

It probably would be possible now days to have it operate off of the CMS. We know there are folks who’ve created LMSs on CMS Hub.
Any examples you can share, to have a look at?
I can only share <https://hublms.io/|HubLMS> as it’s the only one I know of that’s a publicly packaged solution. <@U25C65C3S> I’m sure would love to chat about it.
Here’s a breakdown of our <https://www.loom.com/share/4304f904c4fd49a8b695e3f7b1912d86|HubLMS enterprise featureset> to which is quiet comparable too
